isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 2000, 4000, 8000 - CHASSIS ACCESSORIES - TROUBLESHOOTING - Trailer Connection, Regular Cab and Sleeper Box

svcproc.title: Trailer Connection, Regular Cab and Sleeper Box

table.title: Testing Trailer Connection, Regular Cab and Sleeper Box

entry.para: Does trailer connection at the back of the cab function properly?
Do the tractor turn signals function properly?
See CAB ACCES- SORIES section for tractor turn signal trouble- shooting.
Does the left turn signal circuit to the trailer function properly?
Remove fuse F27 and check for open condition.
Locate cause of overload condition, then repair. Replace fuse.
Re-install fuse F27 and at fuse and circuit 14G, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 14G/14S, then repair.
Remove relay (R5), and at the socket and circuit 56K, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 56K, then repair.
At relay socket (R5), measure voltage from circuit 56K to 56-GA.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 56-GA/ 11-GF, then repair.
Move turn signal switch to left turn position and at relay socket (R5) circuit 56F, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no pulsating voltage in circuit 56F, then repair.
Bench test relay (R5) by measuring the resistance from terminal 30 to 87A.
Bench test relay (R5) by applying +12V to terminal 86 and ground at 85. Then measure resistance from terminal 30 to 87.
Re-install relay (R5) and at conn. (182) and circuit 56E, measure voltage to ground with left turn signals switched on.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 56E, then repair.
Disconnect conn. (12) and with left turn signals switched on, measure voltage from circuit 56H to gnd.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 56H, then repair.
Reconnect conn. (12) and at conn. (149), with left turn signal switched on, measure voltage from cir. LT TURN to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit LT TURN, then repair.
Does right turn signal circuit to the trailer function properly?
Remove fuse F28 and check for open condition.
Locate cause of overload condition, then repair. Replace fuse.
Re-install F28. At fuse and cir. 14H, measure voltage to gnd.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 14H/14S, then repair.
Remove relay (R6), and at the socket and circuit 57K, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 56K, then repair.
At relay socket (R6), measure voltage from circuit 57K to 57-GA.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 57-GA/ 11-GF, then repair.
Move turn signal sw. to right turn position and at relay socket (R6) circuit 57F, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 57F, then repair.
Bench test relay (R6) by measuring the resistance from term. 30 to 87A.
Bench test relay (R6) by applying +12V to term. 86 and ground to 85. Then measure resistance from term. 30 to 87.
Re-install relay (R6) and at conn. (182) and cir. 57E, measure voltage to gnd. with right turn signals switched on.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 57E, then repair.
Disconnect conn. (12) and with right turn signals switched on, measure voltage from circuit 57H to gnd.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 57H, then repair.
Reconnect conn. (12) and at conn. (149), with right turn signals switched on, measure voltage from cir. RT TURN to gnd.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit RT TURN, then repair.
Does the tail light circuit to the trailer function properly?
Do the tractor tail/ marker lights function properly?
See LIGHT SYSTEMS section for tractor tail light trouble- shooting.
Disconnect conn. (78) and with headlight switch in the park or headlight position, measure voltage from cir. 68B to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 68B, then repair.
Reconnect conn. (78) and with the headlight switch in the park or headlight position, measure voltage at (149) from circuit TAIL to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit TAIL, then repair.
Does the marker light circuit to the trailer function properly?
Do the tractor marker/ tail lights function properly?
See LIGHT SYSTEMS section for tractor tail light trouble- shooting.
Disconnect conn. (78) and with the headlight sw. in the park or headlight position, measure voltage from cir. 68A to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 68A, then repair.
Reconnect conn. (78) and with headlight sw. in the park or headlight position, measure voltage at (149) from cir. MARKER to gnd.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit MARKER, then repair.
Does the stop light circuit to the trailer function properly?
Do tractor stop lights function properly?
See LIGHT SYSTEMS section for tractor tail light trouble- shooting.
Remove fuse F29 and check for open condition.
Locate cause of overload condition, then repair. Replace fuse.
Re-install fuse F29 and at fuse and circuit 14J, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 14J/14S, then repair.
Remove relay (R4), and at the socket and circuit 70C, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 70C, then repair.
At relay socket (R4), measure voltage from circuit 70C to 70-G.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 70-G or 11-G to cab ground, the repair.
While an assistant applies the service brakes, at relay socket (R4) circuit 70D, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 70D, then repair.
Bench test relay (R4) by measuring the resistance from terminal 30 to 87A.
Bench test relay (R4) by applying +12V to term. 86 and gnd. to 85. Then measure resistance from term. 30 to 87.
Re-install relay (R4), and disconnect conn. (160). At (160) while an assistant applies service brakes, measure voltage to ground at circuit 70E.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuits 70F or 70E, then repair.
Reconnect conn. (160) and disconnect (149). At (149) and circuit STOP, measure voltage to ground while an assistant applies service brakes.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit STOP, then repair.
At conn. (149) and circuit GROUND, measure resistance to ground.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit GROUND, rear cab ground, circuit 11-GD/ 11-GF or front cab ground, then repair.
Does the trailer connection at the back of the sleeper box function properly?
Do the tractor turn signals function properly?
See CAB ACCES- SORIES section for tractor turn signal trouble- shooting.
Does the left turn signal circuit to the trailer function properly?
Remove fuse F27 and check for open condition.
Locate cause of overload condition, then repair. Replace fuse.
Re-install fuse F27 and at fuse and circuit 14G, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 14G/14S, then repair.
Remove relay (R5), and at the socket and circuit 56K, measure voltage to gnd.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 56K, then repair.
At relay socket (R5), measure voltage from circuit 56K to 56-GA.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 56-GA/ 11-GF, then repair.
Move turn signal switch to the left turn position and at relay socket (R5) circuit 56F, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 56F, then repair.
Bench test relay (R5) by measuring the resistance from term. 30 to 87A.
Bench test relay (R5) by applying +12V to term. 86 and gnd. to 85. Then measure resistance from term. 30 to 87.
Re-install relay (R5) and at conn. (182) and cir. 56E, measure voltage to ground with left turn signals switched on.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 56E, then repair.
Disconnect conn. (12) and with left turn signal switched on, measure voltage from circuit 56H to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 56H, then repair.
Reconnect conn. (12) and disconnect (707). At conn. (707), with left turn signals switched on, measure voltage from cir. LT TURN to gnd.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit LT TURN, then repair.
Reconnect conn. (707) and at conn. (149), with left turn signals switched on, measure voltage from circuit 56B to gnd.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 56B, then repair.
Does right turn signal circuit to the trailer function properly?
Remove fuse F28 and check for open condition.
Locate cause of overload condition, then repair. Replace fuse.
Re-install F28 and at fuse and circuit 14H, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 14H/14S, then repair.
Remove relay (R6), and at the socket and circuit 57K, measure voltage to gnd.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 57K, then repair.
At relay socket (R6), measure voltage from circuit 57K to 57-GA.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 57-GA/ 11-GF, then repair.
Move turn signal sw. to right turn position and at relay socket (R6) circuit 57F, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 57F, then repair.
Bench test relay (R6) by measuring the resistance from terminal 30 to 87A.
Bench test relay (R6) by applying +12V to terminal 86 and ground to 85. Then measure resistance from term. 30 to 87.
Re-install relay (R6) and at conn. (182) and cir. 57E, measure voltage to gnd. with right turn signals switched on.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 57E, then repair.
Disconnect conn. (12) and with right turn signals switched on, measure voltage from circuit 57H to gnd.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 57H, then repair.
Reconnect conn. (12) and disconnect (707). At (707), with right turn signals switched on, measure voltage from circuit RT TURN to gnd.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit RT TURN, then repair.
Reconnect conn. (707) and at conn. (149) with right turn signals switched on, measure voltage from circuit 57B to gnd.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 57B, then repair.
Does the tail light circuit to the trailer function properly?
Do the tractor tail/ marker lights function properly?
See LIGHT SYSTEMS section for tractor tail light trouble- shooting.
Disconnect conn. (78) and with headlight switch in the park or headlight position, measure voltage from circuit 68B to gnd.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 68B, then repair.
Reconnect conn. (78) and disconnect conn. (707). At (707) with headlight switch in the park or headlight position, measure voltage from circuit TAIL to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit TAIL, then repair.
Reconnect conn. (707) and at conn. (149) with headlight switch in the park or headlight position, measure voltage from circuit 68 to gnd.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 68, then repair.
Does the marker light circuit to the trailer function properly?
Do the tractor marker/ tail lights function properly?
See LIGHT SYSTEMS section for tractor tail light trouble- shooting.
Disconnect conn. (78) and with the headlight sw. in the park or headlight position, measure voltage from circuit 68A to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 68A, then repair.
Reconnect conn. (78) and disconnect conn. (707). At (707) with headlight sw. in the park or headlight position, measure voltage from circuit MARKER to gnd.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit MARKER, then repair.
Reconnect conn. (707) and at conn. (149) with headlight sw. in the park or headlight position, measure voltage from circuit 58J to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 58J, then repair.
Does the stop light circuit to the trailer function properly?
Do tractor stop lights function properly?
See LIGHT SYSTEMS section for tractor tail light trouble- shooting.
Remove fuse F29 and check for open condition.
Locate cause of overload condition, then repair. Replace fuse.
Re-install fuse F29 and at fuse and circuit 14J, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 14J/14S, then repair.
Remove relay (R4) and at the socket and circuit 70C, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 70C, then repair.
At relay socket (R4), measure voltage from circuit 70C to 70-G.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 70G or 11-G, to cab ground, then repair.
While an assistant applies the service brakes, at relay socket (R4) circuit 70D, measure voltage to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 70D, then repair.
Bench test relay (R4) by measuring the resistance from term. 30 to 87A.
Bench test relay (R4) by applying +12V to term. 86 and gnd. to 85. Then measure resistance from term. 30 to 87.
Re-install relay (R4) and disconnect conn. (160). Turn key on and at conn. (160), while an assistant applies the service brakes, measure voltage to ground at circuit 70E.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuits 70F or 70E, then repair.
Reconnect conn. (160) and disconnect conn. (707). At (707) and circuit STOP, measure voltage to ground while an assistant applies the service brakes.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit STOP, then repair.
Reconnect conn. (707) and disconnect conn. (149). Turn key on and at conn. (149) circuit 70G, measure voltage to ground while an assistant applies the service brakes.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 70G, then repair.
At conn. (149) and circuit GROUND, measure resistance to ground.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit GROUND, then repair.
Trailer connections at the back of the sleeper box function properly.
